subject: Re: TDD Using NetBeans 6.5+ and JUnit.

Not necessarily. Just wondering if anyone had devised an automated method f=
or doing this. Sounds like maybe a plugin addition in the works if not.
~Ka=
rl

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <david@...> wrote:
>
> Karl,
>=
 
> Eclipse also has a UI feature that will automatically create a JUnit
> =
test case class from an existing class.  I never use it.  Instead, I
> manu=
ally create test classes.  Does NetBeans make this more difficult?
> 
>    =
David Saff
> 
> On Sun, Apr 19, 2009 at 6:18 PM, Karl Krasnowsky <karlkras@=
...> wrote:
> > This question is really targeted to those who have used Ken=
t Beck's book, Test-Driven Development within the context of the NetBeans I=
DE, otherwise please disregard.
> >
> > Maybe someone here can provide a po=
inter to already available information on this.
> > I'm using Kent Beck's b=
ook, Test-Driven Development as a tutorial and was looking at how i might u=
se NetBeans with its JUnit plugin to mimic his recommended processes, but r=
ight out of the gate I'm having a fundamental issue.
> > A standard practic=
e of KB's method is to code the test before any code is written, and then b=
ackfill the empty bits (class, methods, variables, etc.) to make the test w=
ork.
> > for example, here's the first JUnit test he shows in chapter 1 to =
begin building from:
> > Code:
> > =A0 =A0public void testMultiplication() =
{
> > =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0Dollar five =3D new Dollar(5);
> > =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0five=
.times(2);
> > =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0assertEquals(10, five.amount);
> > =A0 =A0}
>=
 >
> > Problem I'm having is, if I'm creating tests out of the context of t=
he Java project, tests in NB aren't created until you have a class with run=
time methods to create tests from. So I have a chicken egg sort of situatio=
n. NB would do the obvious thing, i.e., have tests generated from code, so =
the above doesn't make any sense as it implies that the code is generated f=
rom the test, which is a cool idea of the IDE could support it.
> > I have =
experience using JUnit, so the framework itself isn't in question, but how =
to apply this methodology within the IDE format is.
> > Do I have to simply=
 short-circuit the default process that NB and the JUnit plugin manufacture=
?
> >
> > thanks in advance for any help on this,
> > Karl
> >
> >
